chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk discusses Berkshire Hathaway's capital allocation and dividend philosophy, emphasizing the importance of retaining earnings only when returns exceed market rates. Buffett explains why Berkshire historically retained earnings rather than paying dividends, illustrating with examples of early businesses that underperformed and the benefits of diversification. The key takeaway is that disciplined capital allocation and retention of earnings only when value is created are central to Berkshire's strategy.
chunks.next_context: The letter transitions to Berkshire's acquisition criteria and approach to buying businesses.
chunks.principle_statement: Earnings should be retained only when they can be reinvested at returns exceeding the cost of capital; otherwise, distributions should be made to shareholders.

chunks.start_anchor:
Our present plan is to use our retained earnings to further
build the capital of our insurance companies. Most of our
competitors are in weakened financial condition and reluctant to
expand substantially. Yet large premium-volume gains for the
industry are imminent, amounting probably to well over $15
billion in 1985 versus less than $5 billion in 1983. These
circumstances could produce major amounts of profitable business
for us. Of course, this result is no sure thing, but prospects
for it are far better than they have been for many years.

Miscellaneous

This is the spot where each year I run my small business
wanted ad. In 1984 John Loomis, one of our particularly
knowledgeable and alert shareholders, came up with a company that
met all of our tests. We immediately pursued this idea, and only
a chance complication prevented a deal. Since our ad is pulling,
we will repeat it in precisely last years form:
chunks.end_anchor:
We invite potential sellers to check us out by contacting people
with whom we have done business in the past. For the right
business - and the right people - we can provide a good home.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk outlines Berkshire Hathaway's acquisition criteria, emphasizing preference for large, simple, consistently profitable businesses with strong management and little debt. Buffett highlights the company's approach of buying for cash or stock only when intrinsic value is matched, and the commitment to confidentiality and speed in deal-making. The key insight is the disciplined, principled approach to acquisitions that avoids turnarounds and complex businesses.
chunks.prev_context: The previous chunk detailed Berkshire's capital allocation and dividend philosophy.
chunks.next_context: The letter then shifts to shareholder matters, including the charitable contributions program.
chunks.principle_statement: Acquire businesses that demonstrate consistent earnings, strong management, and simplicity, avoiding turnarounds and complex technologies.

chunks.section_title: Shareholder-Designated Contributions Program and Annual Meeting
chunks.start_anchor:
A record 97.2% of all eligible shares participated in
Berkshires 1984 shareholder-designated contributions program.
Total contributions made through this program were $3,179,000,
and 1,519 charities were recipients. Our proxy material for the
annual meeting will allow you to cast an advisory vote expressing
your views about this program - whether you think we should
continue it and, if so, at what per-share level. (You may be
interested to learn that we were unable to find a precedent for
an advisory vote in which management seeks the opinions of
shareholders about owner-related corporate policies. Managers
who put their trust in capitalism seem in no hurry to put their
trust in capitalists.)
chunks.end_anchor:
We always have bragged a bit on these pages about the
quality of our shareholder-partners. Come to the annual meeting
and you will see why. Out-of-towners should schedule a stop at
Nebraska Furniture Mart. If you make some purchases, youll save
far more than enough to pay for your trip, and youll enjoy the
experience.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk describes Berkshire Hathaway's shareholder-designated charitable contributions program, noting record participation and the upcoming advisory vote on its continuation. It also discusses the annual meeting's unique atmosphere, emphasizing thoughtful shareholder engagement and encouraging attendance. The key point is the company's commitment to shareholder involvement and community support.
chunks.prev_context: The previous chunk detailed Berkshire's acquisition criteria and approach.
chunks.next_context: The letter concludes with a subsequent event describing a major investment in Capital Cities Communications.

chunks.section_title: Subsequent Event: Capital Cities Communications Investment

Warren E. Buffett
February 25,1985 Chairman of the Board

Subsequent Event: On March 18, a week after copy for this
report went to the typographer but shortly before production, we
agreed to purchase three million shares of Capital Cities
Communications, Inc. at $172.50 per share. Our purchase is

chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk reports a subsequent event where Berkshire Hathaway agreed to purchase three million shares of Capital Cities Communications contingent on its acquisition of American Broadcasting Companies. Buffett praises the management of Capital Cities, highlighting their ability and integrity. The key insight is the strategic investment in a high-quality media company with strong leadership.
